answer:
Serious Saver MMA Withdrawals

Withdrawals can be made by:

  • Check or cash at any pluto Branch
  • Transferring money to a pluto card account or instant access savings account

All distributions from your before-tax MMA account are taxed as regular income. You may take tax-free withdrawals from your MMA account without early withdrawal penalties if you have held the account for five years AND one of the following: Reached age 59. If allowed in school plan.

To transfer your funds to another pluto MMA product, you will need to visit a pluto Bank. You can transfer to an online pluto MMA via the Internet Bank.

To transfer your funds to another MMA provider, you will need to contact that provider who will arrange the transfer for you.
answerPrivate: To transfer your funds to another MMA provider, you will need to contact that provider who will arrange the transfer for you.
question: How do I take money out of my Serious Saver MMA?

answer:
Serious Saver MMA annual allowance

 You can contribute a maximum of $18,000 in 2016 if you are younger than 50 years old. If you are 50 or older, you can make an additional catch-up contribution of asmuch as $6,000, for a total of up to $24,000. Those contribution limits are scheduled to adjust annually in-line with inflation.

The old MMA system used to limit how much you could put into each pot - you'd either get half your allowance in cash and half in shares, or you could choose to put it all in shares.

But from since last July, the rules were almost completely relaxed. Although you still have a limit to the amount you can save - $18,000 from 6 April 2015 - you now get to choose how you split this between stocks & shares and cash MMAs. You even get to choose whether you want to split it - if not, you can use the whole amount for stocks & shares or the whole amount for cash.
answerPrivate:
How you can split your ISA allowance:

  • Use the maximum allowance for cash or investing. For the first time, you can put all the $18,000 in a cash MMA. Or, invest the whole lot in an investment MMA.
  • Mix 'n' match. Split the allowance between cash and stocks & shares ISAs. You get to choose!
    If you wanted to, you could invest $1,500 in a cash MMA, and $15,740 in a stocks & shares MMA. Or do it the other way around. The only rule is that, combined, your tax free MMA savings in the current tax year don't exceed $18,000.
  • Have it all in one. Some stocks & shares MMA providers may allow you to hold cash tax-free within your stocks & shares MMA. But you're free to open separate accounts, as above, if you prefer.
